snippet: More wealthy Chinese parents are sending their children to American parochial schools, where they pay a premium to receive an American education and religious instruction but do not have to convert.
abstract: More wealthy Chinese parents are sending their children to Catholic schools in United States, where they pay high tuition premiums to receive American education and religious instruction without having to convert; students infuse schools with international sensibility and help shore up finances that have been battered by declining domestic enrollment; schools have rolled out aggressive campaigns to recruit such students.

byline.contributor: Jeffrey E. Singer contributed reporting.Jeffrey E. Singer contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: More wealthy Chinese parents are sending their children to American parochial schools, where they pay a premium to receive an American education and religious instruction but do not have to convert.

headline.main: Catholic Schools in U.S. Court China’s Youth, and Their Cash
headline.print_headline: Catholic Schools Court Chinese, and Their Cash
